metadata.title: Trump says he’ll keep extending TikTok shutdown deadline

left: Trump has extended the TikTok shutdown deadline three times, with the next deadline set for September 17.
The first extension occurred on January 20 after a national ban, followed by a second extension in April amid failed negotiations for a U.S.-owned company.
A Pew Research Center survey shows support for a TikTok ban dropped to about one-third, down from 50% in March 2023.
Trump described concerns over TikTok's security and privacy as 'highly overrated' and plans to extend the deadline until a buyer is found.
center: President Donald Trump has extended the deadline for TikTok's U.S. operations divestment until September 17, delaying a national ban.
This extension follows a 2024 law requiring ByteDance to divest TikTok's U.S. assets, although the administration has delayed enforcement and the spin-off deal collapsed after China withdrew.
Trump said they have American buyers lined up, will monitor security concerns, and plans to extend the deadline until the complex situation resolves.
Trump called privacy and national security concerns about TikTok 'highly overrated' and noted he used TikTok in his campaign and is a fan of the platform.
The ongoing extensions highlight political division, as a recent Pew survey showed about one-third of Americans support a TikTok ban, down from 50% in March 2023.
right: President Donald Trump has extended the deadline for TikTok's U.S. operations divestment until September 17, delaying a national ban.
This extension follows a 2024 law requiring ByteDance to divest TikTok's U.S. assets, although the administration has delayed enforcement and the spin-off deal collapsed after China withdrew.
Trump said they have American buyers lined up, will monitor security concerns, and plans to extend the deadline until the complex situation resolves.
Trump called privacy and national security concerns about TikTok 'highly overrated' and noted he used TikTok in his campaign and is a fan of the platform.
The ongoing extensions highlight political division, as a recent Pew survey showed about one-third of Americans support a TikTok ban, down from 50% in March 2023.

sources.news_title: President Trump says he’ll keep extending TikTok shutdown deadline
sources.text:
WASHINGTON — President Donald Trump is calling national security and privacy concerns related to TikTok and its Chinese parent company “highly overrated” and said Friday he’ll keep extending the deadline for the popular video-sharing platform until there’s a buyer.
Congress approved a U.S. ban on TikTok unless its parent company, ByteDance, sold its controlling stake. But Trump has so far extended the deadline three times during his second term — with the next one coming up on Sept. 17.
“We’re gonna watch the security concerns,” Trump told reporters, but added, “We have buyers, American-buyers,” and “until the complexity of things work out, we just extend a little bit longer.”
The first extension was through an executive order on Jan. 20, his first day in office, after the platform went dark briefly when a national ban — approved by Congress and upheld by the U.S. Supreme Court — took effect. The second was in April, when White House officials believed they were nearing a deal to spin off TikTok into a new company with U.S. ownership that fell apart after China backed out following Trump’s tariff announcement.
His comments follow the White House starting a TikTok account this week.
“I used TikTok in the campaign,” Trump said.
“I’m a fan of TikTok,” he said. “My kids like TikTok. Young people love TikTok. If we could keep it going.”
As the extensions continue, it appears less and less likely that TikTok will be banned in the U.S. any time soon. The decision to keep TikTok alive through an executive order has received some scrutiny, but the administration has not faced a legal challenge in court — unlike many of Trump’s other executive orders.
Americans are even more closely divided on what to do about TikTok than they were two years ago.
A recent Pew Research Center survey found that about one-third of Americans said they supported a TikTok ban, down from 50% in March 2023. Roughly one-third said they would oppose a ban, and a similar percentage said they weren’t sure.
Among those who said they supported banning the social media platform, about 8 in 10 cited concerns over users’ data security being at risk as a major factor in their decision, according to the report.

Congress approved a U.S. ban on TikTok unless its parent company, ByteDance, sold its controlling stake. But Trump has so far extended the deadline three times during his second term — with the next one coming up on Sept. 17.
“We’re gonna watch the security concerns,” Trump told reporters, but added, “We have buyers, American-buyers,” and “until the complexity of things work out, we just extend a little bit longer.”
The first extension was through an executive order on Jan. 20, his first day in office, after the platform went dark briefly when a national ban — approved by Congress and upheld by the U.S. Supreme Court — took effect. The second was in April, when White House officials believed they were nearing a deal to spin off TikTok into a new company with U.S. ownership that fell apart after China backed out following Trump’s tariff announcement.
His comments follow the White House starting a TikTok account this week.
“I used TikTok in the campaign,” Trump said.
“I’m a fan of TikTok,” he said. “My kids like TikTok. Young people love TikTok. If we could keep it going.”

sources.news_title: Ticker: Trump says he’ll keep extending TikTok shutdown deadline; Cracker Barrel unveils a new logo
sources.text:
President Donald Trump is calling national security and privacy concerns related to TikTok and its Chinese parent company “highly overrated” and said Friday he’ll keep extending the deadline for the popular video-sharing platform until there’s a buyer.
Congress approved a U.S. ban on TikTok unless its parent company, ByteDance, sold its controlling stake. But Trump has so far extended the deadline three times during his second term — with the next one coming up on Sept. 17.
“We’re gonna watch the security concerns,” Trump told reporters, but added, “We have buyers, American-buyers,” and “until the complexity of things work out, we just extend a little bit longer.”
Cracker Barrel unveils a new logo
Cracker Barrel is marching forward with an ongoing makeover. And to the dismay of some fans, the chain’s new logo now ditches the barrel itself.
Or rather, the drawing many have associated with Cracker Barrel over the years. The man leaning on that barrel is also gone, as are the words “Old Country Store.” Instead, the new emblem features a simpler design with just “Cracker Barrel” written on a gold background, which also has a semi-updated shape.
“Anchored in Cracker Barrel’s signature gold and brown tones, the updated visuals will appear across menus and marketing collateral,” the Tennessee-based company wrote in a Tuesday announcement. Cracker Barrel added that its logo is “now rooted even more closely to the iconic barrel shape and word mark that started it all.”

sources.news_title: Trump says he may extend TikTok ban deadline again
Trump says he’ll keep extending TikTok shutdown deadline
sources.text:
Trump says he’ll keep extending TikTok shutdown deadline
Trump says he’ll keep extending TikTok shutdown deadline
WASHINGTON (AP) — President Donald Trump is calling national security and privacy concerns related to TikTok and its Chinese parent company “highly overrated” and said Friday he’ll keep extending the deadline for the popular video-sharing platform until there’s a buyer.
Congress approved a U.S. ban on TikTok unless its parent company, ByteDance, sold its controlling stake. But Trump has so far extended the deadline three times during his second term — with the next one coming up on Sept. 17.
“We’re gonna watch the security concerns,” Trump told reporters, but added, “We have buyers, American-buyers,” and “until the complexity of things work out, we just extend a little bit longer.”
The first extension was through an executive order on Jan. 20, his first day in office, after the platform went dark briefly when a national ban — approved by Congress and upheld by the U.S. Supreme Court — took effect. The second was in April, when White House officials believed they were nearing a deal to spin off TikTok into a new company with U.S. ownership that fell apart after China backed out following Trump’s tariff announcement.
His comments follow the White House starting a TikTok account this week.
“I used TikTok in the campaign,” Trump said.
“I’m a fan of TikTok,” he said. “My kids like TikTok. Young people love TikTok. If we could keep it going.”
As the extensions continue, it appears less and less likely that TikTok will be banned in the U.S. any time soon. The decision to keep TikTok alive through an executive order has received some scrutiny, but the administration has not faced a legal challenge in court — unlike many of Trump’s other executive orders.
Americans are even more closely divided on what to do about TikTok than they were two years ago.
A recent Pew Research Center survey found that about one-third of Americans said they supported a TikTok ban, down from 50% in March 2023. Roughly one-third said they would oppose a ban, and a similar percentage said they weren’t sure.
Among those who said they supported banning the social media platform, about 8 in 10 cited concerns over users’ data security being at risk as a major factor in their decision, according to the report.

sources.news_title: After joining TikTok, Trump says he could extend sale deadline if needed
sources.text:
WASHINGTON (Reuters) -President Donald Trump has U.S. buyers lined up for TikTok and could further extend the deadline for China-based ByteDance to divest the app's U.S. assets, he said on Friday, days after the White House joined the short video platform.
Speaking to reporters, Trump dismissed bipartisan security concerns over TikTok, saying his administration would watch for any problems. He said he would talk to Chinese President Xi Jinping "at the right time."
The Republican president has repeatedly opted not to enforce the deadline following passage of a 2024 law requiring that TikTok stop operating by January 19 of this year. He recently pushed the deadline to September 17.
The White House joined the app on Tuesday.
"I haven't spoken to President Xi about it," Trump told reporters during a visit to a White House gift shop across the street from the presidential residence. "In the meantime, until the complexity of things work out, we just extend a little bit longer."
"We have very substantial American buyers that want to buy it," he added, without naming any individuals or companies.
Asked if he was concerned about privacy or national security, Trump said: "I'm really not. I think it's highly overrated ... I'm a fan of TikTok."
Last year's law requires ByteDance to divest of the app's U.S. assets or demonstrate significant progress toward a sale. Trump opted not to enforce it after taking office on January 20.
Some lawmakers have criticized the delay, arguing his administration is flouting the law and ignoring national security concerns related to Chinese control over TikTok.
(Reporting by Trevor Hunnicutt, Andrea Shalal and Katharine Jackson; Writing by Susan Heavey; Editing by Joe Bavier)

sources.news_title: Trump May Extend TikTok Sale Deadline - Khaama Press
sources.text:
President Trump said U.S. concerns over TikTok are exaggerated and suggested he may extend ByteDance’s deadline to sell its American assets, despite lawmakers’ security warnings.
President Donald Trump has signaled he may extend the deadline for Chinese tech giant ByteDance to divest its TikTok assets in the United States.
Speaking to reporters on August 22, Trump downplayed national security fears surrounding the app, saying concerns had been “exaggerated” but insisted his administration was monitoring potential risks closely.
He added that he intends to discuss the issue with Chinese President Xi Jinping “at the appropriate time,” suggesting the matter could feature in broader U.S.-China negotiations.
The current deadline for ByteDance to either sell or restructure its U.S. holdings has already been postponed until September 17. Trump noted there are “significant American buyers” interested in TikTok, though he declined to name them.
Last year’s legislation requires ByteDance to divest its U.S. operations or show clear progress toward a sale. However, Trump has repeatedly delayed implementation since taking office, citing diplomatic considerations and economic factors.
The debate reflects growing tension in Washington over Chinese ownership of TikTok. While some lawmakers argue that extending the deadline ignores mounting national security concerns, Trump insists a more measured approach is needed to avoid unnecessary disruption.
Analysts say Trump’s latest comments highlight the delicate balancing act between safeguarding digital security and maintaining stable economic ties with Beijing. The outcome could reshape both TikTok’s future in the U.S. and the broader trajectory of U.S.-China tech relations.

sources.news_title: Trump Suggests Possible Extension For TikTok Sale Deadline - Pakistan Live News
sources.text:
Just days after the White House joined TikTok, US President Donald Trump on Friday indicated that he may extend the deadline for China-based ByteDance to sell its US assets and said that American buyers are ready to acquire it.
Speaking to reporters, Trump dismissed bipartisan security concerns over TikTok, saying his administration would watch for any problems. He said he would talk to Chinese President Xi Jinping “at the right time.”
The Republican president has repeatedly opted not to enforce the deadline following passage of a 2024 law requiring that TikTok stop operating by January 19 of this year. He recently pushed the deadline to September 17.
The White House joined the app on Tuesday.
“I haven’t spoken to President Xi about it,” Trump told reporters during a visit to a White House gift shop across the street from the presidential residence. “In the meantime, until the complexity of things work out, we just extend a little bit longer.”
“We have very substantial American buyers that want to buy it,” he added, without naming any individuals or companies.
Asked if he was concerned about privacy or national security, Trump said: “I’m really not. I think it’s highly overrated … I’m a fan of TikTok.”
Last year’s law requires ByteDance to divest of the app’s US assets or demonstrate significant progress toward a sale. Trump opted not to enforce it after taking office on January 20.
Some lawmakers have criticised the delay, arguing his administration is flouting the law and ignoring national security concerns related to Chinese control over TikTok.

sources.news_title: Trump to keep extending TikTok shutdown deadline
sources.text:
President Donald Trump stated he will keep extending the TikTok shutdown deadline until a buyer with American ownership is secured for the Chinese-owned app.
Trump described the national security and privacy concerns linked to TikTok and its parent company ByteDance as “highly overrated.”
Driving the news: Congress passed a law to ban TikTok unless ByteDance sells its controlling stake, but Trump has already extended the deadline three times during his second term. The next extension deadline is set for September 17.
- The first extension was issued via executive order on January 20, the first day of Trump’s second term, following a brief TikTok shutdown under a national ban upheld by the Supreme Court.
- The second extension happened in April when White House officials expected a deal to spin off TikTok to U.S. ownership; however, China backed out after Trump announced tariffs.
Go deeper: The White House recently launched its own TikTok account, with Trump expressing positive personal sentiments, stating he used TikTok during his campaign and that young people, including his own children, enjoy the platform.
- Public opinion on TikTok remains deeply split; a Pew Research Center survey found about one-third of Americans support banning the app, down from 50% in early 2023, with data security concerns driving most supporters of a ban.
- No legal challenges have yet been brought against the executive orders extending TikTok’s operation, unlike other Trump administration directives.
